Authors: Sevda Rezaei, Masoud Abrinbana, youbert Ghosta
Title:
Taxonomic and pathogenic characterization of Phytopythium
species from West Azarbaijan province of Iran, with description of
Phytopythium babaiaharii and P. longitubum spp. nov.
Abstract:
Phytopythium is a globally distributed genus whose species
are found in various ecological niches. Despite their importance as
plant pathogens, information on species diversity and their distribution
in West Azarbaijan, Iran, is very limited. This study was aimed to
investigate taxonomy and plant pathogenicity of Phytopythium isolates
recovered from soils in the province. A polyphasic taxonomy based on
morphological, cultural and multilocus sequence data revealed two new
species, described here as P. babaiaharii and P. longitubum. In
addition, a putatively new species and five known species, P. boreale,
P. carbonicum, P. mercuriale, P. ostracodes and P. vexans, were found in
the studied regions. Phytopythium ostracodes, P. mercuriale and P.
boreale were the three most frequent species isolated from soil although
P. mercuriale was only found in one field. Among the studied species, P.
mercuriale, P. ostracodes and P. vexans exhibited various levels of
pathogenicity on sugar beet, sunflower and tomato, and P. boreale was
documented for first time as a plant pathogen. Phytopythium ostracodes
was highly aggressive on sugar beet and sunflower but lowly aggressive
on tomato whereas P. vexans exhibited high aggressiveness toward the
three crop plants. Both P. boreale and P. mercuriale were found to be
lowly aggressive on the host plants. The results indicated that members
of Phytopythium particularly plant pathogenic species are common in
arable soils of West Azarbaijan province and can pose a threat to
agricultural crops in the region.
